title: Vision Zero Street Redesign: Cross-Sectoral Systems Map
description: Cross-sectoral dependencies showing how reallocating 20% road space to pedestrians/cycles and implementing 40 km/h speed limits affects other sectors

nodes.label: Transport
nodes.description: Vision Zero: 20% road space to pedestrians/cycles + 40 km/h speed limits + protected lanes

nodes.label: Air Quality
nodes.description: PM2.5 reduction, emissions from active mobility shift

nodes.label: Neighbourhoods
nodes.description: Street safety, walkability, community mobility patterns

nodes.label: Urban Development
nodes.description: Public space design, street infrastructure, land use patterns

nodes.label: Industry
nodes.description: Freight movement, delivery logistics, commercial operations

nodes.label: Buildings
nodes.description: Bike parking, delivery access, street-facing retail

nodes.label: Biodiversity
nodes.description: Urban green corridors, street trees, habitat connectivity

nodes.label: Food & Agriculture
nodes.description: Local food markets, walkable food access, delivery logistics

links.quantification: Protected lanes + speed limits → 90K deaths prevented over 10 years → 60% reduction in pedestrian/cyclist fatalities
Safer walking/cycling → 30% modal shift for <5km trips → 20 MT fuel saved/year → PM2.5 reduction in residential areas
20% road space reallocation → 2,500 km² public space reclaimed → street plazas, markets, green corridors become viable
Protected cycle lanes → 500 km green street corridors → urban tree canopy + habitat connectivity for birds and pollinators
Speed limit resistance: 40% of drivers oppose 40 km/h limits → enforcement challenges → requires 10K speed cameras + ₹500 fines
Freight operator pushback: Protected lanes reduce truck lane capacity by 20% → delivery time increase → logistics cost +5%
Delivery access disruption: Curbside loading zones reduced → building service access affected → requires off-peak delivery windows
Safer streets → more children walking to school → parents feel confident → cycling adoption increases → further traffic calming demand
Requires enforcement infrastructure: 10K speed cameras + automated fines + 5K traffic wardens → ₹8K Cr investment needed
Via walking adoption: 30% modal shift for short trips → reduced cold-start emissions → 15% PM2.5 reduction in residential zones
Via walkable streets: 2,500 km² public space → street markets viable → local food retail +25% → fresh food access improves
Via cycling adoption: 30% mode shift → bike parking demand surge → 500K new cycle stands + building code updates required
Via pedestrianization: Safer streets → foot traffic +40% → local business viability → neighborhood economic revitalization
Via emissions reduction: Lower PM2.5 → healthier street trees → 20% increase in urban canopy survival → bird habitat improvement
Walkable streets → 40% more foot traffic → farmers markets + street vendors viable → local food access +25%
Via green corridors: Protected cycle lanes with tree planting → 500 km habitat connectivity → pollinator migration routes restored
Via bike infrastructure: Buildings add cycle parking → 20% increase in cycling → reduced neighborhood traffic congestion
